2.5.2

### Reproduction link
[https://codepen.io/hudk114/pen/deyJRz?editors=1010](https://codepen.io/hudk114/pen/deyJRz?editors=1010)

### Steps to reproduce
open console

### What is expected?
在nextTick中如果有DOM操作则使用macrotask执行

### What is actually happening?
在同一次eventloop中，在当前task中先定义一个非DOM操作（microtask）再触发一次DOM操作，后者会被microtask而非macrotask执行

---
尤大您好。
刚开始啃源码，看到了https://github.com/vuejs/vue/blob/dev/src/core/util/next-tick.js里nextTick的实现有些疑问。
注释中写到nextTick采用macrotask是为了处理一些不能像microtask那样优先级过高、执行过快的事件，其中注册的这一段

```
  if (!pending) {
    pending = true
    if (useMacroTask) {
      macroTimerFunc()
    } else {
      microTimerFunc()
    }
  }
```

我的理解是，pending保证了多个nextTick只会注册一个TimerFunc。那么，当macroTimeFunc先被调用时，所有的nextTick都会被推迟到下一个macrotask执行，这是符合文档里所说的DOM更新（我理解是DOM数据更新）完成后再执行的做法的；但是，如果是microTimeFunc先被调用，而在同一个task片内又紧接着调用了一个需要macrotask执行的nextTick（比如DOM操作），那后者也会被microtask执行，就如同demo里给出的那样。
这种情况下，DOM事件还是如同2.4之前那样被microtask执行，是否还会触发原本的问题呢？

在实验中我并没有试出#6566那样microtask在冒泡过程中执行的问题，所以我并不确定在这种情况下使用microtask对DOM操作是否会有影响。
这几天刚开始看源码，恶补了下这块和eventloop的知识，不是很确定我理解的正确。如果理解错了，还请尤大见谅。谢谢！

Issues.Title: `this.$scopedSlots.default()` returns VNode directly or array of VNodes depending on content
Issues.Body:
### Version
2.5.16

### Reproduction link
[https://jsfiddle.net/50wL7mdz/323954/](https://jsfiddle.net/50wL7mdz/323954/)

### Steps to reproduce
1. Create a component that uses a render function to return some parent element with `this.$scopedSlots.default({})` as the children.
2. Create an instance of that component that passes multiple elements to the scoped slot and see `this.$scopedSlots.default({})` return an array.
3. Create an instance of that component that passes a single element to the scoped slot and see `this.$scopedSlots.default({})` return a VNode, **not an array with a single VNode in it**.

### What is expected?
`this.$scopedSlots.default({})` should always return an array of VNodes, even if there's only one VNode in the array.

This is how `this.$slots.default` behaves.

### What is actually happening?
`this.$scopedSlots.default({})` returns mixed types: an array when there are multiple elements in the slot, or a direct VNode instance if there is only a single child.

---
This is inconsistent with how regular slots behave in render functions, and means any render function component rendering scoped slots as children needs to type check the result of invoking the slot to decide if it needs to be wrapped in an array:

```js
render(h) {
  const children = this.$scopedSlots.default({})
  return h('div', {}, Array.isArray(children) ? children : [children])
}
```

Contrast that with regular slots where it is always safe to pass the slot as a child because it is always an array:

```js
render(h) {
  return h('div', {}, this.$slots.default)
}
```

It's a bummer because although this is pretty easy to classify as a bug, it would be a breaking change for a lot of people using scoped slots to write components that use the default scoped slot as their root element:

```js
render() {
  return this.$scopedSlots.default({ someDataThisComponentIsResponsibleFor })
}
```

If this bug were fixed, anyone with a component like that would need to re-write it like this:

```js
render() {
  return this.$scopedSlots.default({ someDataThisComponentIsResponsibleFor })[0]
}
```

If this isn't a bug and is by design, I'd love to better understand the reasoning!

Issues.Title: v-if with <picture> fires load event on removal
Issues.Body:
### Version
2.5.16

### Reproduction link
[https://jsfiddle.net/degal13/eywraw8t/45236/](https://jsfiddle.net/degal13/eywraw8t/45236/)

### Steps to reproduce
1. Create a picture element with multiple working source child-elements.
2. Attach load event handler to img tag within picture element.
3. Toggle wrapper element or elements themselves with v-if
4. Check how many times load event fires.

### What is expected?
Removing picture elements with v-if should not cause additional firing of the load event on the image.

### What is actually happening?
Removing picture elements with v-if is causing additional firing of the load event on the image.

---
Im working on a project where I have a modal that loads in `<picture>` elements using v-for. The modal itself is triggered via v-if and the picture elements have a handler on the load event (`@load`).

In my specific use case, its important to have accurate firing of the load event. The problem is that when I close the modal, the same picture elements are firing the load callback and that should not happen. It doensnt happen with regular `<img/>` elements.

If you remove the `<source>` elements, then the problem stops so it looks like it has something to do with the sources triggering the load event.

Issues.Title: Have template compiler add source metadata to HTML tags
Issues.Body:
### What problem does this feature solve?
I'm developing an all-in-one editor for webdevs that runs inside Chrome DevTools.

Just by replacing `npm start` with `[name-not-finalized] start`, users can have a fully featured text editor right inside Chrome DevTools shell, automatically pointing at their project directory.

It comes with DOM inspector, where you pick an element and it'll literally take you to `file:line:col` where that element was defined. So you don't have to look through files to figure out where that button below the header is coming from. Useful when a new dev joins a project or you're revisiting your work after a very long time.

▶ [Watch 30 sec demo w/ a React project](http://goo.gl/d64cgv)

___

And of course, it also works with Vue projects, just as awesome.

▶ [Watch 20 sec demo w/ a Vue project](https://drive.google.com/open?id=1rGeFiNLezxzaJqnhnDbjvD_OvLMyaMIh)

Above demos were shot using locally tinkered compilers (just not clean enough to be a PR)

The goal is to deliver the ultimate developer experience ever. Other features are in development as we speak, like CSS QuickEditing, built-in image editor and a SVG editor so devs don't have to fire up Illustrator or Photoshop to make minor tweaks to their stuff.

The only hurdle in me releasing the app is getting external players to participate in revolutionizing how we write web.

So to wrap up I have only two requests:
- Please have the template compilers add metadata to each tag (either as data attribute, or property on DOM node itself), that contains path to `*.vue` file (can be relative to project root), `line:col`/offset where the tag opens and last `line:col`/offset where the tag closes.

- Please star this issue: https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=811036

### What does the proposed API look like?
Something like this:
```javascript
console.log(someElement.__vue__._debugSource)
// > { file: 'src/components/Header.vue', line: 12, col: 4, lineEnd: 16, col: 8 }
// or
// > { file: 'src/components/Header.vue', start: 241, end: 352 }
```

Issues.Title: Allow option to adjust url encoding by path-to-regex
Issues.Body:
### What problem does this feature solve?
If you need to use a permalink system, where your API routes need to use a path to get the response. An example of this is using Vue as a frontend for Wordpress, but allowing wordpress to dictate the url structure.

So for example

would have a route that looks like:
```
{
      name: 'post',
      path: '/:permalink([0-9] [/][0-9] [/][\\S] )',
      component: StandardArticle
}
```
and a page would have a route that looks like:
```
{
     name: 'page',
     path: '/:permalink*',
     component: StandardPage
}
```

This would mean a post url would look like
/2018/04/some-post
and a page would look like
/some-page

The regular expressions work but when you actually try to use them it would look like 
/2018%2F04%2Fsome-post
for the post route, page route would look fine since it does not have a / normally

I see this is an option in path-to-regex but the option is not forwarded to vue-router. This means that if a path would have a / it would be urlencoded by path-to-regex and makes it seemingly impossible to get around (at least I have not found a way around it).

This would have additional benefits of, for instance being able to not urlencode but instead change / with _ or even encode it to base64 or something.

### What does the proposed API look like?
It would just be passing the second parameter of path to regexp's compile function to the route.
```
{
     name: 'post',
     path: '/:permalink([0-9] [/][0-9] [/][\\S] )',
     compile: {
         encode: (value, token) => value
     },
     component: StandardArticle
},
```
https://github.com/pillarjs/path-to-regexp#compile-reverse-path-to-regexp

https://github.com/vuejs/vue-router/blob/dev/src/util/params.js
on line 20 is where it would need to be passed in some way, `{ pretty: true }` is where the encoding can be changed.

Issues.Title: Extra params should be ignored
Issues.Body:
### What problem does this feature solve?
I have a route defined like this:

```
{path: '/entities/:id', component: () => import("...."), name: 'entity', props: true}
```

Then, I have a loaded `entity` instance in my code, so in order to create a link, I need to write:

```
<router-link :to="{name: 'entity', params: {id: myEntity.id}}">Link</router-link>
```

Being lazy, I was slightly less explicit about params and relying on the fact that `entity` contains an `id` field required by the route, I have created the link in the following way:

```
<router-link :to="{name: 'entity', params: myEntity}">Link</router-link>
```

Glad it worked for quite a long time, until I discovered that all extra parameters are not ignored but added to the `<router-view>` element as html attributes. So, for example, if the `myEntity` contains a `name` property besides the `id`, the `id` prop is properly consumed by the component but all the others are left on HTML element produced by `router-view`.

```
<div name="Name from entity">
```

IMO, all extra parameters (not defined in the route) should be ignored and not passed as `props` to the element.

What do you think?

I know there are at least two solutions: 1. not being lazy and 2. use function mode of the `props` to extract only props that are defined in the route. But I think this should be a default behavior.

Fun fact: I have discovered it when `myEntity` contained a `hidden: true` property and it resulted in `hidden="true"` HTML attribute on the whole `router-view`. You can guess how big WTF I had when debugging it... :-)

### What does the proposed API look like?
API does not change.

Issues.Title: Enhancement on reusable router view
Issues.Body:
### What problem does this feature solve?
Use a shared router view among different route paths. I'm creating a dashboard dynamically, which only need three views:

1. List View
2. Create View
3. Edit View

Let's create three files: `PageList.vue`, `PageCreate.vue`, `PageEdit.vue`, and use them in routes.

### What does the proposed API look like?
```js
routes = [
   {path: '/users', component: PageList},
   {path: '/users/create', component: PageCreate},
   {path: '/users/:id', component: PageEdit},
   {path: '/posts', component: PageList},
   {path: '/posts/create', component: PageCreate},
   {path: '/posts/:id', component: PageEdit},
]
```

Currently, this won't work properly. Actually, it has a bug, the `poll` function will run infinitely when switching routes.


## Current Bug

If you have such routes, and using navigation guard, the `poll` function will run infinitely when switching routes.

```js
routes = [
   {path: '/users', component: PageList},
   {path: '/posts', component: PageList},
]
```

If you add a `console.log` here https://github.com/vuejs/vue-router/blob/dev/src/history/base.js#L315
it will print log infinitely, because `instances[key]` will always be undefined.

My current solution:

```js
routes = [
   {path: '/users', component: Object.assign({}, PageList)},
   {path: '/posts', component: Object.assign({}, PageList)},
]
```

<!-- generated by vue-issues. DO NOT REMOVE -->

Issues.Title: Allow paths with trailing slash.
Issues.Body:
### What problem does this feature solve?
Right now if I specify a route with "path: '/about/'" and I redirect to it the browser URL will be set to '.../about'.

This creates various issues. For example, Google Analytics will report usage statistics about '/about' and '/about/' (the latter we get if the user arrives on our page at /about as the browser appends a slash). Clearly this should be fixed on our end and I'm sure there are a lot of other cases where this creates problems. 

### What does the proposed API look like?
Disclaimer: I don't know if this breaks something else.

It would be great if "path: '/about/'" would add a trailing slash when redirecting to the route.

`store._modules.root.state` and `store._modules.root.context.state` should both reference the new state object

`store._modules.root.state` instead still references the old (detached) state object
